revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2017}} {{refimprove|date=June 2017}} }} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Crimean chamber | logo = Logo KS.jpg | logo_size = 200px | logo_alt = | image = KS-04-2017.pdf | image_size = 150px | image_alt = | caption = One of the issues of the newspaper ''Crimean chamber'' | motto = | type = Weekly newspaper | format = B4 | owners = [[Ministry of Culture of Ukraine]] | founder = [[Ministry of Culture of Ukraine]], [[Prosvita Society]], SE "National newspaper and magazine publishing" | publisher = SE «National newspaper and magazine publishing» | editor = Victor Merzhvynskyy (since 2016) | assoceditor = | maneditor = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | foundation = {{Start date|1992|12|31}} | political = | language = [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] | headquarters = Vasylkivska str., 1
[[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] 03040 | publishing_country = [[Ukraine]] | circulation = 1000 | ISSN = | oclc = | website = {{URL|http://svitlytsia.in.ua}} }} '''''Crimean chamber''''' ({{lang-uk|Кримська світлиця}}, in transliterated form "Krymska svitlytsia") is the only national Ukrainian newspaper in Crimea. It is published since 31 December 1992.{{cite web|url=https://www.radiosvoboda.org/a/news/27638027.html|title=Українськомовна газета «Кримська світлиця» більше не виходитиме у Криму|website=Радіо Свобода}} Its profile changed more than once during its existence, sometimes covering mostly social and political topics, sometimes becoming more literary and historical in its content, but always focusing on Crimean themes. Since 2006 the "Crimean chamber" editorial works as a part of the state-owned enterprise (SE) "National newspaper and magazine publishing". As a result of the [[Russian occupation of Crimea]] in March 2014, the publisher had to stop the printed version of newspaper since February 2015, so that for over a year the newspaper existed only in electronic format. However, by an order of the publisher's board of directors in May 2016 the newspaper's editorial got evacuated from the occupied peninsula to Kiev, and after a forced break, since July 2016 the publishing of the printed version of "Crimean chamber" resumed in [[Kiev]]. The entire editorial staff of the newspaper "Crimean chamber" are people from [[Crimea]].{{cite web|url=http://detector.media/infospace/article/116734/2016-07-12-u-kievi-povidomili-pro-vidnovlennya-prodazhu-gazeti-krimska-svitlitsya/|title=У Києві повідомили про відновлення продажу газети «Кримська світлиця»|publisher=}} Since 2017 is published under [[CC-BY 3.0]] license.{{cite web|url=http://uacrisis.org/ua/54348-kultura-zhittya-ta-krimska-svitlitsya-perejshli-na-vilnu-litsenziyu|title=Видання «Культура і життя» та «Кримська світлиця» перейшли на вільну ліцензію – головні редактори видань - UACRISIS.ORG|date=28 March 2017|publisher=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Krymska svitlytsa}} * {{official|http://svitlytsia.in.ua/ }} {{uk icon}} * [https://www.facebook.com/Кримська-світлиця-851133848354987 Facebook page] [[Category:1992 establishments in Ukraine]] [[Category:Publications established in 1992]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Kiev]] {{Ukraine-newspaper-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox single | Name = Crisalide (Vola) | Cover = Crisalide.jpg | Border = yes | Artist = [[Valentina Monetta]] | from Album = La storia di Valentina Monetta | Released = 15 March 2013 | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Recorded = 2012 | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | Length = 2:56 | Label = | Writer = Mauro Balestri, [[Ralph Siegel]] | Producer = [[Ralph Siegel]] | Last single = "[[The Social Network Song]]"
(2012) | This single = "'''Crisalide (Vola)'''"
(2013) | Next single = "[[Maybe (Valentina Monetta song)|Maybe (Forse)]]"
(2014) | Misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{Flag icon|San Marino}} "Crisalide (Vola)" | image = | caption = | year = 2013 | country = San Marino | artist = [[Valentina Monetta]] | as = | with = | language = Italian | languages = | composer = [[Ralph Siegel]] | lyricist = Mauro Balestri | place = | points = | place_semi = 11th | points_semi = 47 | lyrics = | prev = The Social Network Song | prev_link = The Social Network Song | next = Maybe | next_link = Maybe (Valentina Monetta song) }}}} "'''Crisalide (Vola)'''" is a song recorded by [[San Marino|Sammarinese]] singer [[Valentina Monetta]]. The song was written by [[Ralph Siegel]] and Mauro Balestri. It is best known as [[San Marino in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013|San Marino's entry]] to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2013]] held in [[Malmö]], [[Sweden]].{{cite web|last=Roxburgh|first=Gordon|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=its_valentina_monetta_again_for_san_marino|title=It's Valentina Monetta again for San Marino|work=Eurovision.tv|date=30 January 2013}} The song competed in the second semi-final on 16 May 2013 for a spot in the final on 18 May 2013, however it failed to qualify. It finished in 11th place with 47 points, which, at the time, was San Marino's best result in the competition before they qualified for the final in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014]] The [[time signature]] of the first part of the song is 12/8, and 4/4 of the second part. An English version of the song, titled "Chrysalis (You'll Be Flying)", was also recorded with lyrics by Timothy Touchton.{{cite web|last=Jiandani|first=Sanjay|url=http://www.esctoday.com/43598/valentina-monetta-to-represent-san-marino-in-malmo/|title=Valentina Monetta to represent San Marino in Malmö|accessdate=30 January 2013|work=ESCtoday}} == Presentation == [[San Marino RTV]] presented the song and music video to the public on 15 March 2013.{{cite web|last=Roxburgh|first=Gordon|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=75503&_t=san_marino_entry_to_be_presented_on_15th_march|title=San Marino entry to be presented on 15th March|work=Eurovision.tv|date=8 March 2013}}{{cite web|last=Roxburgh|first=Gordon|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=watch_the_official_video_of_crisalide|title=Watch the official video of "Crisalide"|work=Eurovision.tv|date=15 March 2013}}{{cite web|last=Jiandani|first=Sanjay|url=http://www.esctoday.com/47907/san-marino-song-presentation-show-on-15-march/|title=San Marino: Song Presentation Show on 15 March|accessdate=8 March 2013|work=ESCtoday.com}} ==Track listing== ;Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/album/crisalide-vola-single/id623787973|title=iTunes - Music - Crisalide (Vola) - Single by Valentina Monetta|work=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=21 March 2013}} # Crisalide (Vola) – 2:56 # Crisalide (Vola) (Karaoke version) – 2:56 ;Digital maxi-single{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.es/Crisalide-vola-Chrysalis-Youll-Flying/dp/B00C58HV84/ref=sr_shvl_album_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1365319337&sr=301-1|title=Crisalide (vola) / Chrysalis (You'll Be Flying): Valentina Monetta: Amazon.es: Tienda MP3|work=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=10 April 2013}} # Crisalide (Vola) – 2:56 # Chrysalis (You'll Be Flying) – 2:56 # Crisalide (Vola) (Karaoke version) – 2:56 # Chrysalis (You'll Be Flying) (Karaoke version) – 2:56 == References == {{Reflist}} {{San Marino in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2013}} [[Category:2013 songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2013]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of San Marino]] [[Category:Valentina Monetta songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Ralph Siegel]] {{2010s-song-stub}} {{SanMarino-stub}}

revision.text:
This is a list of the '''extreme points of [[Luxembourg]]''', the points that are farther [[north]], [[south]], [[east]] or [[west]], [[elevation|higher or lower]] than any other location in the territory of the state.
[[Image:MostNpointInLux.jpg|thumb|The northernmost point of Luxembourg]] ==Latitude and longitude== *Northernmost point — in [[Schmëtt]] ({{coord |50|10|58.6|N|6|1|28.66|E|region:LU_type:landmark|name=near Huldange (North)}}) *Southernmost point — near [[Rumelange]] ({{coord|49|26|52|N|6|02|0|E|region:LU_type:landmark|name=near Rumelange (South)}}) *Easternmost point — on [[Sauer]] River near [[Rosport, Fënterwier]] ({{coord|49|49|N|6|32|E|region:LU_type:waterbody|name=Sauer river near Rosport (East)}}) *Westernmost point — near [[Surré]] ({{coord|49|54|N|5|44|E|region:LU_type:waterbody|name=near Surré (West)}})
[[Image:Kneiff.jpg|thumb|Kneiff, the highest point in the country]]
==Elevation== *Highest point — [[Kneiff]], in [[Troisvierges]] (559.8 [[metre|m]]) ({{coord|50|09.439|N|6|02.220|E|type:mountain_region:LU|name=Kneiff (highest)}}) *Lowest point — confluence of Sauer and [[Moselle]] Rivers, in [[Wasserbillig]] (129.9 [[metre|m]]) ({{coord|49.713|N|6.5065|E|region:LU_type:landmark}})
==See also== *[[Extreme points of Earth]] *[[Geography of Luxembourg]]
{{Luxembourg topics}} {{Extreme points of Europe}}
[[Category:Geography of Luxembourg]] [[Category:Extreme points by country|Luxembourg]] [[Category:Luxembourg geography-related lists|Extreme]]
{{Luxembourg-stub}}

revision.text:
{{one source|date=November 2011}} Baron '''Gaston de Gerlache de Gomery''' ([[Brussels]], 17 November 1919 – [[Oudenaarde]], 13 July 2006) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] polar explorer.
Gaston de Gerlache was the son of [[Adrien de Gerlache]] and followed in the tracks of his father by leading the second Belgian expedition to [[Antarctica]] in 1957-1958, 60 years after his father led the 1897-1899 [[Belgica_Expedition|Belgian Antarctic Expedition]] with the ship [[RV Belgica (1884)|Belgica]].
Gaston de Gerlache and his crew established the [[Baudouin I of Belgium|King Baudouin]] Base in 1958 in the context of the [[International Geophysical Year]]. On [[December 11]], [[1958]] an aircraft with four Belgians, led by Gaston de Gerlache crashed in Crystal Mountains, 250 km from King Badouin Base, Antarctica. The crew was searched for and rescued on [[December 16]] by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] polar pilot V. M. Perov on [[Li-2]] aircraft, that took off from [[Mirny Station]].<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015019278947;view=1up;seq=456 Rescue of Belgian Plane Crew in Antarctic], Soviet Bloc International Geophysical Year Information, January 16, 1959, U. S. Department of Commerce, pp. 18-19</ref>
In 1960 Gaston de Gerlache published his travel journal ''Retour dans l'antarctique''. A year later he made a documentary about his expedition named ''Plein sud''.
An article, "Belgium in the Antarctic", written by Gaston de Gerlache de Gomery appeared in the Geographical magazine (May 1962 issue).
[[Mount Gaston de Gerlache]] in the [[Queen Fabiola Mountains]] on Antarctica was named after him.
== References == <references/>
==External links == * {{nl}} [http://www.trends.be/nl/archief/1996/07%20november%201996/Gaston+de+Gerlache-5686-179663.html Artikel in Trends over Gaston de Gerlache]{{dead link|date=August 2014}}
{{Polar exploration|state=collapsed}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gerlache, Gaston de}} [[Category:Belgian explorers]] [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]]
{{Belgium-stub}}

{{Infobox forest | name = Hareskoven | native_name = | native_lang = | native_name2 = | native_lang2 = | photo = Hareskoven.jpg | photo_caption = Hareskoven viewed from Fægyden | photo_width = | map = Denmark | map_caption = | map_width = | coordinates = {{coord|55|46|N|12|23|E|display=inline,title}} | county = [[Furesø Municipality|Furesø]], [[Gladsaxe Municipality|Gladsaxe]] | region = | country = [[Denmark]] | elevation = | area = {{convert|8.08|km2|abbr=on}} | max_area = | date_max_area = | status = | established = | visitation = | visitation_year = | events = | authority = | website = | ecosystem = | classification_WWF = | classification_EPA = | classification_CEC = | disturbance = | forest_cover = | species = | indicator_plants = | lesser_flora = | fauna = }} '''Hareskoven''' or '''Hareskovene''' (plural) is a forested area straddling the boundary between [[Fresø Municipality|Furesø]] and [[Gladsaxe Municipality|Gladsaxe]] municipalities in the northwestern suburbs of [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Fægyden, a road between [[Hareskovby]] and [[Værløse]], separates '''Store Hareskov''' in the west from '''Lille Hareskov''' to the west. The forested area has a combined area of c. 808 hectares.
==History== The first part of the name (Hare- or Harre-) is derived from the Norse word ''[[Hörgr]]'', meaning altar or cult site.
Hareskov was severely damaged during the [[Dano-Swedish War (1658–60)|Swedish Wars]] in the late 1650s. At the end of the war it was concluded that "the forest will only be able to feed 90 pigs". It was therefore protected for the next few years while it recovered.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://naturstyrelsen.dk/naturoplevelser/naturguider/hareskovene/historie/historie/#Kongelig_jagtskov|language=Danish|publisher=DNaturstyrelsen|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==Ecology== Harskov consists mainly of [[beeach|beech forest]] with scattered oak, linden and maple trees. Notable solitaire trees include the three ancient oak trees Skrædderen "The Tailor"), Grenaderen and Djævelen /"The Devil"). The latter used to look like a devil's hand reaching out for the sky. It was partly destroyed in a storm in 1981 but is still alive.
==Historic features== Hareskoven contains a total of six [[dolmen]]s from the Stone Age. The largest one is located close to Sandskredshus at [[Skovbrynet station]].
Two examples of earthworks from the Swedish Ears known as Lejrens Indelukke and Svenskervolden can still be seen in the southern part of the forest.
==Activities== Hareskoven forest contains a network of [[bridle path]]s for horseback riding as well as a trail for mountain biking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://naturstyrelsen.dk/publikationer/2014/sep/hareskovene/|title=Hareskovene|language=Danish|publisher=DNaturstyrelsen|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons}} * [http://naturstyrelsen.dk/naturoplevelser/naturguider/hareskovene/ Hareskovene]
{{Copenhagen northwestern suburbs}}
[[Category:Forests of Greater Copenhagen]] [[Category:Furesø Municipality]] [[Category:Gladsaxe Municipality]]
{{Denmark-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox political post |post = Head |body = the
Mari El Republic |flag = |flagsize = 220px |flagcaption = |insignia = Coat of Arms of Mari El.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = Coat of arms of Mari El |image = Meeting Vladimir Putin with Alexander Yevstifeyev 2017-04-06 02 cropped.jpg |incumbent = [[Alexander Yevstifeyev]] |incumbentsince = {{start date |2017|09|21}} |department = Government of the Mari El Republic
|style = [[Mr. President (title)|Mr. President]] (1991 to June 2011)
Head (June 2011 to present)
([[Mari language|Mari]]: '''Вуйлатышыже''', ''Vuylatyshyzhe'')
({{lang-ru|'''Глава'''}}, ''Glava'') |member_of = Government of the Mari El Republic |residence = |seat = |appointer = Direct popular vote |termlength = Five years |termlength_qualified = |constituting_instrument = |formation = 24 December 1991 |first = |salary = |website = }} The '''Head of the Republic of Mari El''' (formerly '''President of Mari El Republic''') is the highest executive position in the [[Mari El Republic]], a [[Federal subjects of Russia|federal subject]] of the [[Russian Federation]]. The first President of Mari El Republic was [[Vladislav Zotin]] when the position was created on December 24, 1991, two days before [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], replacing the [[First Secretary of the Mari Communist Party]], the equivalent position of the [[Mari ASSR]] before it was succeeded by the Mari El Republic. The status and powers of the President were determined by Chapter 4 of the Constitution of the Mari El Republic. In December 2010, Russian President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] signed a law that forbade calling the heads of federal subjects as "president", and must bring their constitutions or statutes in conformity with the law before January 1, 2015. The position of President of Mari El Republic was renamed to Head (''Vuylatyshyzhe'' in [[Mari language|Mari]]) in June 2011. Since 6 April 2017 the Head of the Mari El Republic is Aleksandr Yevstifeyev. ==List of Heads of the Mari El Republic== {| class=wikitable border=1 style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- ! colspan=2|Row ! Portait ! Name ! Party ! Took office ! Left office |- ! 1 |style="background:{{Communist Party of the Russian Federation/meta/color}}"| | [[File:Vladislav Zotin.jpg|150px]] | [[Vladislav Zotin]] | [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation|Communist Party]] | 24 December 1991 | 5 January 1997 |- ! 2 |style="background:{{Communist Party of the Russian Federation/meta/color}}"| | [[File:Vyacheslav Kislitsyn.jpg|150px]] | [[Vyacheslav Kislitsyn]] | [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation|Communist Party]] | 5 January 1997 | 14 January 2001 |- ! 3 |style="background:{{United Russia/meta/color}}"| | [[File:Leonid Markelov 2010.jpg|150px]] | [[Leonid Markelov]] | [[Liberal Democratic Party of Russia|Liberal Democratic Party]]
↓
[[United Russia]] | 14 January 2001 | 6 April 2017 |- ! rowspan=2|4 |rowspan=2 style="background:{{United Russia/meta/color}}"| | rowspan=2|[[File:Meeting Vladimir Putin with Alexander Yevstifeyev 2017-04-06 02 cropped.jpg|150px]] | rowspan=2|[[Alexander Yevstifeyev]] |rowspan=2|[[United Russia]] | style="background:lightyellow"|6 April 2017 | style="background:lightyellow"|21 September 2017 |- | 21 September 2017 | Incumbent |} ==Elections== The latest election for the office was held on 10 September 2017 {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right ! colspan=2|Candidates ! revision.comment: Clean up [[:Category:Pages using duplicate arguments in template calls|duplicate template arguments]] using [[User:Frietjes/findargdups|findargdups]]

revision.text:
{{morefootnotes|date=February 2016}} '''Karelianism''' was a late 19th-century cultural [[phenomenon]] in the [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] and involved writers, painters, poets and sculptors. Since the publishing of the Finnish national epic [[Kalevala]] in 1835, compiled from [[Karelia]]n folk lore, culture spheres in [[Finland]] became increasingly curious about Karelian heritage and landscape. By the end of the 19th century Karelianism had become a major trend for many works of art and literature in Finland. In the movement Karelia was seen as a sort of refuge for the essence of "Finnishness" that had maintained its [[Authenticity in art|authenticity]] across centuries. The phenomenon can be interpreted as a Finnish version of European [[national romanticism]].
The painters [[Akseli Gallen-Kallela]] and [[Louis Sparre]] are usually mentioned as the founders of the movement. They were soon joined by the sculptor [[Emil Wikström]], the writers [[Juhani Aho]], [[Eino Leino]] and [[Ilmari Kianto]], the composers [[Jean Sibelius]] and [[P.J. Hannikainen]], the architects [[Yrjö Blomstedt]] and [[Victor Sucksdorff]], and many others. <ref>[http://www.juminkeko.fi/viena/en/karelianismi.html Karelianism]</ref>
Later, towards the [[Second World War]], some of the ideas of Karelianism were taken over by an irredentist movement aspiring to create a larger Finland. Thus some of the ideas put forward by Karelianism were used as a motivation to the proposal of a [[Greater Finland]], a single state encompassing many [[Finnic people]]s.
==See also== *[[Heimosodat]] *[[Romantic nationalism]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading== *[http://www.publiscan.fi/wtf02e.htm Welcome to Finland - Culture] *[http://finland.fi/public/default.aspx?contentid=160078&contentlan=2&culture=en-US Kalevala: the finnish national epic -thisisFINLAND] *[http://finland.fi/public/default.aspx?contentid=160079&contentlan=2&culture=en-US The Kanteletar -thisisFINLAND] *[http://finland.fi/public/default.aspx?contentid=162922&contentlan=2&culture=en-US Travel broadens the Kalevala-thisisFINLAND] *[http://www.juminkeko.fi/viena/en/karelianismi.html Info on Karelianism from Juminkeko, a foundation maintaining the Kalevala tradition]
[[Category:Grand Duchy of Finland]] [[Category:Finnish culture]] [[Category:Karelia]]
{{finland-stub}}

{{about|kitchen gods in European mythology|the Chinese Kitchen God|Kitchen God}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} '''Kitchen gods''' are [[mythology|mythical]] beings that represent abstract concepts such as [[luck]] or just propel the minor changes of everyday life. Little things that cannot be explained, such as losing small objects like socks in the laundry are often attributed to these creatures because the explanation eludes the believer.
== Kitchen gods of the world == * [[Jowangsin]] is a Korean kitchen god. * [[Zàojūn]] is a Chinese kitchen god. * [[Kōjin]] is a Japanese kitchen god.
== See also == *[[List of deities]] *[[Household deity]]
[[Category:European mythology]]
{{europe-myth-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox presenter |name = Lynn Parsons |image = |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = |nationality = British |death_date = |death_place = |show = |station = |timeslot = |show2 = |station2 = [[Magic 105.4 FM]] (2016-)
[[Jazz FM (UK)|Jazz FM]] (2014-2015)
[[Smooth Radio]] (2007–2014)
[[BBC Radio 2]] (1998–2014)
[[Absolute Radio|Virgin Radio]] (1996–1998)
[[BBC Radio 1]] (1991–1996)
[[Capital London|Capital Radio]] (1987–1991) |timeslot2 = |style = Presenter |country = [[United Kingdom]] |prevshow = |web = [http://www.lynnparsons.net/ Official website] }} '''Lynn Parsons''' is a British [[disc jockey]]. ==Career== Having graduated from college with an [[BTEC ND|OND]] in electronic principles, Parsons started her career working in the television industry, where she was a sound engineer and later a vision mixer. She was a DJ on the [[UK pirate radio#1970s and 1980s|pirate]] soul station JFM before moving to a Saturday night pop music programme at County Sound in Guildford.[https://books.google.com/books?id=LZ-RpGjFavoC&pg=PT66&dq=KISS+%22Lynn+Parsons%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8C-YUKSZKuTRyQH-vYDwDA&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Lynn%20Parsons%22&f=false KISS FM: From Radical Radio To Big Business] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509091252/http://books.google.com/books?id=LZ-RpGjFavoC&pg=PT66&dq=KISS+%22Lynn+Parsons%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8C-YUKSZKuTRyQH-vYDwDA&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA |date=9 May 2014 }} By Grant Goddard In radio, she joined London's [[Capital London|Capital FM]] in 1987 as a weeknight presenter, before moving to [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] in 1991. Initially she was an overnight presenter, but later hosted other shows, and during her time with the network she became the last person to interview the comedian [[Peter Cook]]. After leaving Radio 1, she joined [[Absolute Radio|Virgin Radio]] in 1996, spending two years as a presenter there. In 1998, Parsons joined [[BBC Radio 2]], taking over the Friday and Saturday Overnight slot, where she remained as a full-time presenter until 2003. She was also briefly a presenter of the weekday late show. In 2001, Parsons' show received two hours of phone calls after rival [[Absolute Radio|Virgin Radio]] DJ [[Jon Holmes]] requested that his listeners call Parsons to request [[John Denver]]'s [[Annie's Song]] be played.{{cite news|page=|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=4 October 2001|section=|title=3am: Annie's Throng|author=Jessica Callan|accessdate=10 November 2012|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-78881283.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924163729/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-78881283.html|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} From 2003 she was a stand-in presenter on the network. She had her own early Sunday morning show on Radio 2 from January to April 2010,{{cite news |first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/11/radio-2-schedule |title=Long-running shows move in Radio 2 reshuffle |publisher=guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=1 February 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224043129/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/11/radio-2-schedule |archivedate=24 February 2016 |df=dmy-all }} and later that year stood in for [[Sarah Kennedy]] after Kennedy was absent from her ''Dawn Patrol'' programme. It was announced on 3 September that Kennedy would not be returning to the network and that Parsons would continue to present the show until a shake up of the Radio 2 schedule in October.{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/03/sarah-kennedy-radio-2|title= Sarah Kennedy to leave BBC Radio 2|publisher= Guardian Media Group|work= The Guardian|first= James|last= Robinson|date= 3 September 2010|accessdate= 3 September 2010|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140924072557/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/03/sarah-kennedy-radio-2|archivedate= 24 September 2014|df= dmy-all}} In January 2012 it was confirmed she would provide cover for the 6{{snd}}8 am Saturday breakfast slot after [[Zoë Ball]] announced her decision to leave the show, and until another regular presenter was appointed.{{cite news |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/01/last-radio-2-saturday-show-for-zoe-ball/ |title=Last Radio 2 Saturday show for Zoe Ball |publisher=Radio Today |date=29 January 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201222228/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/01/last-radio-2-saturday-show-for-zoe-ball/ |archivedate=1 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} She joined [[102.2 Smooth Radio]] in London following its launch in March 2007,{{cite news |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2007/03/parsons-and-allen-join-smooth/ |title=Parsons and Allen join Smooth |publisher=Radio Today |date=21 March 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728074915/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2007/03/parsons-and-allen-join-smooth/ |archivedate=28 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|page=2|newspaper=[[Music Week]]|date=31 March 2007|section=|title=Smooth Radio finalises new line-up|author=|accessdate=10 November 2012|url=http://business.highbeam.com/411456/article-1G1-161213660/brief-smooth-radio-finalises-new-lineup|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227213140/http://business.highbeam.com/411456/article-1G1-161213660/brief-smooth-radio-finalises-new-lineup|archivedate=27 February 2014|df=dmy-all}} later becoming a presenter on its successor, Smooth Radio. From October 2010 she was the breakfast show presenter on the new national Smooth Radio, a role which was taken over by [[Simon Bates]] when Bates joined the network in January 2011.{{cite news |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2010/10/smooth-radio-goes-national/ |title=Smooth Radio goes national |publisher=Radio Today |date=4 October 2010 |accessdate=31 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219041544/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2010/10/smooth-radio-goes-national/ |archivedate=19 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Parsons then returned to the weekend mid-morning show. In October 2012 Parsons was confirmed as the new host of the weekday mid morning show on Smooth, replacing [[Mark Goodier]] from December. She would be succeeded as weekend presenter by [[David Prever]], who was previously a stand-in presenter at the network.{{cite news |url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/parsons-replaces-goodier-on-smooth-radio/ |title=Parsons replaces Goodier on Smooth Radio |publisher=Radio Today |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024105637/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/10/parsons-replaces-goodier-on-smooth-radio/ |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Parsons left Smooth Radio on 28 February 2014.{{cite news |first=John |last=Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/feb/24/simon-bates-dropped-smooth-radio |title=Simon Bates dropped by Smooth Radio |newspaper=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian Media Group |date=24 February 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302210812/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/feb/24/simon-bates-dropped-smooth-radio |archivedate=2 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }} On 11 September 2014, the ''[[Radio Today (website)|Radio Today]]'' website reported that Parsons would join Jazz FM to present the station's breakfast show, ''The Jazz Breakfast''. She joined Jazz FM from 15 September as part of an overhaul of their schedule.{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/09/lynn-parsons-to-host-jazz-fm-breakfast/|title=Lynn Parsons to host Jazz FM Breakfast|work=Radio Today|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=21 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913151117/http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/09/lynn-parsons-to-host-jazz-fm-breakfast/|archivedate=13 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} She left Jazz FM on Friday 2 October 2015. Her hobbies and interests include Feng Shui, science, the paranormal, English literature, antiques and swimming. She is a regular participant in the 26 mile moonlight walkathon.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/presenters/lynn-parsons/ |title=Radio 2 - Presenters - Lynn Parsons |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=31 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003111336/http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/presenters/lynn-parsons/ |archivedate=3 October 2010 |df=dmy-all }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.lynnparsons.net}} *[https://planetradio.co.uk/magic/presenters/lynn-parsons/ Lynn Parsons on Magic 105.4] *[https://planetradio.co.uk/mellow-magic/presenters/lynn-parsons-mellow/ Lynn Parsons on Mellow Magic] {{Absolute Radio|state=autocollapse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Parsons, Lynn}} [[Category:British radio personalities]] [[Category:Virgin Radio (UK)]] [[Category:British radio DJs]] [[Category:BBC Radio 1 presenters]] [[Category:BBC Radio 2 presenters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.comment: it's open to the public when the flag is on the tower
revision.text:
{{Infobox military installation | name = Sciuta Tower | native_name = Torri ta' Xutu | partof = the [[Lascaris towers]] | location = [[Qrendi]], [[Malta]] | image = Ta Sciuta Tower.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Sciuta Tower | type = [[Coastal defence and fortification|Coastal]] [[watchtower]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|49|9.62|N|14|27|12.97|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | ownership = [[Government of Malta]] | controlledby = [[Din l-Art Ħelwa]] | open_to_public = Yes | built = 1638 | used = 1638–1873
1940s | builder = [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of Saint John]] | materials = [[Limestone]] | height = | condition = Intact | battles = [[World War II]] }} '''Sciuta Tower''' ({{lang-mt|Torri ta' Xuta}}), also known as '''Sciutu Tower''' ({{lang-mt|Torri ta' Xutu}}) or '''Wied iż-Żurrieq Tower''' ({{lang-mt|Torri ta' Wied iż-Żurrieq}}), is a small [[watchtower]] in [[Qrendi]], [[Malta]]. It was completed in 1638 as the fifth of the [[Lascaris towers]]. The tower was in a dilapidated state but it is currently being restored by [[Din l-Art Ħelwa]]. ==History== Sciutu Tower was built in 1638 in Wied iż-Żurrieq, close to [[Qrendi]], on the site of a medieval watch post.{{cite journal|last1=Zammit|first1=Vincent|title=Fortifications in the Middle Ages|journal=Civilization|date=1984|volume=1|page=33|publisher=PEG Ltd|location=[[Ħamrun]]}} It served as the prototype for the [[De Redin towers]], which were built between 1658 and 1659.{{cite web|last1=Attard|first1=David P.|title=The De Redin Tower|url=http://afm.gov.mt/file.aspx?f=496|website=[[Armed Forces of Malta]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YvvlFucJ|archivedate=31 May 2015}} After the British took over Malta in 1800, Sciutu Tower remained in use and was manned by the Royal Malta Fencible Regiment and later the Royal Malta Fencible Artillery. It was abandoned in 1873 but was manned by the Coast Police once again during [[World War II]]. The tower subsequently used as a police station until 2002. An original cannon dating back to the Order's rule can still be found on the tower's roof. ==Present day== [[File:Torri ta’ Xutu 2009.JPG|thumb|left|The tower viewed from the east]] In March 2013, [[Din l-Art Ħelwa]] was entrusted by the Government with the conservation of this tower for a period of 10 years.{{cite news|title=Din l-Art Helwa to manage Wied iż-Żurrieq Tower|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20130306/local/din-l-art-helwa-to-manage.460364|accessdate=20 April 2014|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=6 March 2013}} In September 2014, the tower and the surrounding area was cleaned of waste and debris by Din l-Art Ħelwa volunteers as well as the Qrendi Scouts.{{cite news|title=Wied iz Zurrieq tower gets much-needed clean-out|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20140907/local/wied-iz-zurrieq-tower-gets-much-needed-clean-out.534755|accessdate=16 September 2014|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=7 September 2014}} The tower underwent restoration conservation until 2016, and is expected to be opened to the public by 2017.{{cite web|title=Corporate Responsibility|url=http://corporate.maltairport.com/en/corporate-social.htm|website=Malta International Airport|accessdate=17 May 2015}} ==Further reading== * Nicola Said (2015). [http://www.nicolasaid.com/#!malta-airport-foundation/v0evm Malta Airport Foundation]. ''nicolasaid.com''. Retrieved 29 June 2016. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Torri ta' Xutu}} *[http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1388.pdf National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands] {{Historic Watch Towers of Malta|west=[[Ħamrija Tower]]|east=[[Wardija Tower]]}} [[Category:Lascaris towers]] [[Category:Defunct police stations in Malta]] [[Category:Towers completed in 1638]] [[Category:Qrendi]] [[Category:National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]] [[Category:1638 establishments in Malta]] {{Malta-struct-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Unified Targeting Tool''' (UTT) is a software program used by [[NSA]] to select targets for surveillance. It has gained attention as one of the programs exposed by [[Edward Snowden]]. It is mentioned as part of the [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program, and in other documents.<ref name =WaPo1>{{cite web|author=Published: June 6, 2013, Updated July 10, 2013 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/prism-collection-documents/ |title=NSA slides explain the PRISM data-collection program |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2013-07-10 |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref>
The screen captures show that the program is a web-based application accessible through an [[intranet]], <!--best guess based on low-res screencap: https://gamut.wakefield.???.nsa --> [[Internet Explorer 6]] is shown in one sample.<ref name=Guardian1>{{cite web|author=Glenn Greenwald |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/31/nsa-top-secret-program-online-data |title=XKeyscore: NSA tool collects 'nearly everything a user does on the internet' | World news |publisher=theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref> The tool has the ability to query at least one database, NYMROD, which appears to be a database of names. <!-- Query Nymrod --> The screen captures suggest that tool has the ability to filter by nationality (it is possible to enter multiple nationalities), <!--see the "add" button --> location, and "target extension" (the given example is "D Diplomatic"). The analyst is also able to enter a classification string, and include a declassification date, in the sample given: 20320108 is code for January 8, 2032. There is a category labeled "Intelligence Purpose Information," in which the analyst is able to select a geopolitical area, topic and subtopic.<ref name =WaPo2>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-broke-privacy-rules-thousands-of-times-per-year-audit-finds/2013/08/15/3310e554-05ca-11e3-a07f-49ddc7417125_story.html |title=NSA broke privacy rules thousands of times per year, audit finds |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref> The screen captures suggest that the tool gives the analyst the option of suggesting how often to forward new intelligence, and enter a reason for any higher priority requests.<ref name=Guardian1/> <!--see: Forwarding precedence, Forwarding precedence reason -->
The tool has the ability to build queries regardless of whether the target's name is known. The target may be a person, but that may not always be the case.<ref name =WaPo2/> The analyst must enter a short justification, and select a foreignness factor.<ref name =Guardian1/><ref name =WaPo2/> Foreign factors include: "person is a user of storage media seized outside the US," "the person has indicated that he is located outside the US," "In direct contact w/ tgt oversees, no info to show proposed tgt in US," among others. The presence of a [[ZIP code]] field on one of the released screen captures suggests that the tool may have the ability to collect within the United States, and not be limited to foreign intelligence gathering. There is a field for "Special Authorization," presumably for targets that the analyst needs special approval to select, such as US persons, or foreigners presently located within the US. <!-- suggested by other documents --> The screen captures suggest that the tool requires the analyst to enter a start and end date for the authorization, and a separate end date for the targeting itself to cease.<ref name =WaPo2/> <!-- Note: see the delayed detasking violations in the reports; not yet clear if the UTT has this issue, but some other programs clearly do -->
According to still undisclosed NSA documents from the collection of Edward Snowden, the UTT replaced the telephony targeting system OCTAVE in 2011.<ref>Marcel Rosenbach & Holger Stark, Der NSA Komplex, Deutsche Verlags-Anstalt, München 2014, p. 344</ref> <!-- Todo: Describe the known fields -->
== Gallery == <gallery perrow=4 widths=250 heights=250> File:Prism-slide-6.jpg|A reference to UTT as part of the PRISM tasking process File:Target-analyst-rationale-instructions-final.pdf|page=3|A screenshot of the UTT File:KS4-001.jpg|A second screenshot showing the interface and foreignness criteria. File:UTT Realms in Analyst Tools (from SIGDEV Presentation).jpg|UTT Screen Capture, from a SIGDEV presentation (not fully legible) </gallery>
== See also == * [[2013 mass surveillance disclosures]] * [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] * [[XKeyscore]]
==References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:National Security Agency]] [[Category:American secret government programs]] [[Category:Surveillance scandals]]

revision.comment: Per [[Template talk:Infobox World Heritage Site#Implementation of RfC]]
revision.text:
{{for|the national park in [[Tasmania, Australia|Tasmania]]|Walls of Jerusalem National Park}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} {{Expand Hebrew|חומות ירושלים|fa=yes|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | image = Jerusalem, city wall.jpg | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = | location = [[Jerusalem]] | part_of = [[Old City of Jerusalem]] and its Walls | criteria = {{UNESCO WHS type|(ii), (iii), (vi)}}(ii), (iii), (vi) | ID = 148rev | coordinates = {{coord|31|47|N|35|13|E|region:IL_type:landmark|display=title, inline|format=dms}} | year = 1981 | danger = 1982–... | embedded = Site proposed by [[Jordan]] | locmapin = Israel | map_caption = }} [[File:547.Walls.Jerusalem (cropped).jpg|thumb|Walls of Jerusalem]] The '''Walls of Jerusalem''' ({{lang-ar|أسوار القدس}}; {{lang-he-n|חומות ירושלים}}) surround [[Old City (Jerusalem)|the Old City of Jerusalem]] (approx. 1 km²). In 1535, when Jerusalem was part of the [[Ottoman Empire]], [[Sultan]] [[Suleiman the Magnificent|Suleiman I]] ordered the ruined city walls to be rebuilt. The work took some four years, between 1537 and 1541.{{cite book |title=The Holy Land: An Oxford Archaeological Guide from Earliest Times to 1700 |series=Oxford Archaeological Guides |author=Jerome Murphy-O’Connor |year=2008 |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=12 |isbn=978-0-19-923666-4 |quote= |url=https://books.google.co.il/books?id=m3Yy9FDcT8gC&pg=PT48&lpg=PT48&dq=%22began+in+the+north+in+1537+and+continued+down+the+east+and+west+sides%22&source=bl&ots=Hv7zZyYFL7&sig=_pxHUiAqEHj3XHuagqxlnm8OJ1M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk7PDUuprKAhUB1BoKHa0eC0oQ6AEIGjAA#v=onepage&q=%22began%20in%20the%20north%20in%201537%20and%20continued%20down%20the%20east%20and%20west%20sides%22&f=false |accessdate=8 January 2016 }}http://www.antiquities.org.il/jerusalemwalls/hstry_12_eng.asp The length of the walls is 4,018 meters (2.4966 mi), their average height is 12 meters (39.37 feet) and the average thickness is 2.5 meters (8.2 feet). The walls contain 34 watchtowers and [[Gates in Jerusalem's Old City Walls|seven main gates]] open for traffic, with two minor gates reopened by archaeologists. In 1981, the Jerusalem walls were added, along with the Old City of Jerusalem, to the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] List.[http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repext81.htm#148 Report of the 1st Extraordinary Session of the World Heritage Committee] ==Pre-Israelite city== The city of Jerusalem has been surrounded by walls for its defense since ancient times. In the Middle [[Bronze Age]], a period also known in [[Hebrew Bible|biblical]] terms as the era of the [[Patriarchs (Bible)|Patriarchs]], a city named [[Jebusite|Jebus]] was built on the [[City of David|southeastern hill]] of Jerusalem, relatively small (50,000 square meters) but well fortified. Remains of its walls are located above the [[Siloam Tunnel]]. The identification of Jebus with Jerusalem has been disputed, principally by [[Niels Peter Lemche]]. Supporting his case, every non-biblical mention of Jerusalem found in the [[ancient Near East]] refers to the city as 'Jerusalem'. An example of these records are the [[Amarna letters]] which are dated to the 14th century BCE, several of which were written by the chieftain of Jerusalem [[Abdi-Heba]] and call Jerusalem either {{lang|akk-Latn|Urusalim}} ({{lang|akk-Latn|URU ú-ru-sa-lim}}) or {{lang|akk-Latn|Urušalim}} ({{lang|akk-Latn|URU ú-ru-ša10-lim}}) (1330s BCE).''Urusalim'' e.g. in EA 289:014, ''Urušalim'' e.g. in [[Amarna letter EA 287|EA 287]]:025. Transcription online at {{cite web |url=http://www.tau.ac.il/humanities/semitic/EA263-end.html |title=''The El Amarna Letters from Canaan'' |publisher=Tau.ac.il |accessdate=11 September 2010}}; translation by [https://archive.org/details/dieelamarnatafel01knud Knudtzon 1915] (English in Percy Stuart Peache Handcock, ''[https://archive.org/stream/selectionsfromte00handuoft#page/10/mode/2up Selections from the Tell El-Amarna letters]'' (1920). Also in the [[Amarna letters]], it is called Beth-Shalem, the house of Shalem.See, e,g,, Holman Bible Dictionary, op. cit. supra. ==Israelite city (ca. 1000–587/86 BCE)== According to Jewish tradition, as expressed in the [[Tanakh]], Jerusalem remained a [[Jebusite]] city until the rise of [[David]], who [[Siege of Jebus|conquered Jebus]], renamed it [[City of David]] and started expanding it. His city was still located on the low southeastern hill, outside today's Old City area. [[Solomon]], David's son, built the [[First Temple]] on the hilltop rising right above the city he had inherited, the [[Temple Mount]], and then extended the city walls in order to protect the temple. During the First Temple period the city walls were extended to include the northwest hill as well, i.e. the area where today's [[Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)|Jewish]] and [[Armenian Quarter (Jerusalem)]] Quarters are located. The entire city was destroyed in 587/86 BCE during the siege led by [[Nebuchadnezzar II|Nebuchadnezzar]] of Babylon. ==Jewish postexilic city== After the [[Babylonian captivity of Judah|Babylonian captivity]] and the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] conquest of Babylonia, [[Cyrus II of Persia]] allowed the Jews to return to Judea and rebuild the Temple. The construction was finished in 516 BCE or 430 BCE. Then, [[Artaxerxes I]] or possibly [[Darius II]] allowed [[Ezra]] and [[Nehemiah]] to return and rebuild the city's walls and to govern Judea, which was ruled as [[Yehud]] province under the Persians. During the Second Temple period, especially during the [[Hasmonean]] period, the city walls were expanded and renovated, constituting what [[Josephus]] calls the First Wall. [[Herod the Great]] added what Josephus called the Second Wall somewhere in the area between today's Jaffa Gate and Temple Mount. [[Agrippa I]] (r. 41–44 CE) later began the construction of the Third Wall, which was completed just at the beginning of the [[First Jewish–Roman War]].[[Josephus]], ''De Bello Judaico'' (''Wars of the Jews'') v.iv.§ 2 Some remains of this wall are located today near the [[Mandelbaum Gate]] gas station. ==Aelia Capitolina and Byzantine Jerusalem== In 70 CE, as a result of the [[Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)|Roman siege]] during the [[First Jewish–Roman War]], the walls were almost completely destroyed. Jerusalem would remain in ruins for some six decades and without protective walls for over two centuries. The pagan Roman city, [[Aelia Capitolina]], which was built after 130 by Emperor [[Hadrian]], was at first left without protective walls. After some two centuries without walls, a new set was erected around the city, probably during the reign of Emperor [[Diocletian]], sometime between 289 and the turn of the century. The walls were extensively renewed by the Empress [[Aelia Eudocia]] during her banishment to Jerusalem (443–460). ==Middle Ages== [[File:Old City of Jerusalem and its Walls-108391.jpg|thumb|[[Damascus Gate]] with its [[crenelations]]]] In 1033, most of the walls constructed by Eudocia were destroyed by an earthquake. They had to be rebuilt by the [[Fatimids]], who left out the southernmost parts that had been previously included: Mount Zion with its churches, and the southeastern hill (the City of David) with the Jewish neighborhoods which stood south of the Temple Mount. In preparation for the expected [[Crusades|Crusader]] siege of 1099, the walls were strengthened yet again but to little avail. The conquest brought some destruction followed by reconstruction, as did the reconquest by [[Saladin]] in 1187. In 1202 to 1212 Saladin's nephew, [[al-Mu'azzam|Al-Malik al-Mu'azzam 'Isa]], ordered the reconstruction of the city walls, but later on, in 1219, he reconsidered the situation after most of the watchtowers had been built and had the walls torn down, mainly because he feared that the Crusaders would benefit of the fortifications if they managed to reconquer the city. For the next three centuries, the city remained without protective walls, the [[Temple Mount]]/Haram ash-Sharif and the [[Tower of David|citadel]] then being the only well-fortified areas. ==Ottoman period== In the 16th century, during the reign of the [[Ottoman Empire]] in the region, Sultan [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] decided to rebuild the city walls fully, partly on the remains of the ancient walls. Being built 1535 and 1538, they are the walls that exist today. An inscription in Arabic from the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent states:
Has decreed the construction of the wall he who has protected the home of Islam with his might and main and wiped out the tyranny of idols with his power and strength, he whom alone God has enabled to enslave the necks of kings in countries (far and wide) and deservedly acquire the throne of the Caliphate, the Sultan son of the Sultan son of the Sultan son of the Sultan, Suleyman.[http://www.imj.org.il/imagine/galleries/viewItemE.asp?case=7&itemNum=374383 Building inscription commemorating the rebuilding of the walls of Jerusalem], Accession number: IAA 1942-265
== See also == * [[Broad Wall (Jerusalem)]] – city wall of Jerusalem from the time of Hezekiah (ca. 700 BCE) * [[Ancient city walls around the City of David]], asserted First Temple-period structures * [[Old City (Jerusalem)#Gates|City gates of the Old City of Jerusalem]] * [[Southern Wall]] of the Temple Mount * [[Western Wall]] – aka '''Wailing Wall''', the accessible part of the western retaining wall of the Temple Mount * [[Walls of Jerusalem National Park]] – a [[national park]] in [[Tasmania]] [[Australia]] named after the Walls of Jerusalem for having natural rock formations that resemble the Walls ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Old City (Jerusalem)}} {{World Heritage Sites in Israel and East Jerusalem|nocat=true}} [[Category:City walls|Jerusalem]] [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Asia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Jerusalem]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Jerusalem]]
